question: Gentlemen, welcome to Air Force One.
answer: We've already been inspected.

question: Sir, this plane carries the President of the United States.
answer: Of course. I'm sorry.

question: I always wondered if my freshman Russian class would come in handy.
answer: Sir, you threw out page two.

question: Goddamn right I did. I asked for a tough-as-nails speech and you gave me diplomatic bullshit. What's the point in having a speech if I have to ad-lib?
answer: It was a good ad-lib, sir.

question: Put together a score sheet. I'll make some calls.
answer: With all due respect, sir, maybe you should give them this one. Your numbers are still pretty low and you called in a lot of chips to nail Stravanavitch.

question: I might still have a few chips left.
answer: * We could always put you in a duck blind with a twelve gauge. The second amendment types'll love that.

question: This is a crime bill, Shep. Killing a couple ducks won't get it through committee. Besides, Shep, I told you... I don't shoot babies and I don't kiss guns.
answer: Other way around, sir.

question: Right... Christ I'm tired. Do me a favor and keep me away from the press.
answer: This is the part I wanted you to see. * My opinion. We can't let him get away with that kind of language.

question: It's bait. Don't take it.
answer: Sir, the Speaker of the House attacked this administration on national television. You can't afford to leave that hanging.

question: Up on the upper deck is the cockpit and the Mission Communication Center. The MCC, as we call it, can place clear and secure phone calls to anywhere on earth. We're linked to a network of military and civilian satellites and ground stations. We could run the country or run a war from there if we had to.
answer: This is a remarkable aircraft.

question: You don't know the half of it. Did you know this entire plane is shielded from radiation? We could fly through a mushroom cloud completely unharmed if necessary.
answer: A dubious distinction, no?

question: I guess it depends on your perspective.
answer: And all these rooms here?

question: Conference rooms, though some have other functions. The one up front doubles as an emergency medical center. As you can see, back here's more like a regular plane. Security and Secret Service take this cabin. You'll be in the rear with the press pool. Here's a press kit. I'll let you guys get comfortable and once we're airborne I'll be able to schedule the interviews.
answer: Thank you.

question: Thank you.
answer: You fellas win some sort of fly-with- POTUS contest?

question: Potus? What is Potus?
answer: P.O.T.U.S. President Of The United States.

question: Ah, no. We won nothing. We are ITAR-TASS news service.
answer: Right. Listen, this here... This is my row. You'll have to sit over there.

question: Mr. President?
answer: Thirty seconds. Yes.

question: Can I at least issue a press release objecting to the Speaker's choice of wording?
answer: I said it's not worth the fight. Steward, please.

question: We'll just say it was in bad taste. You give me ulcers.
answer: That's my job. Hey Mike. Could you get me a Heineken?

question: No, wait. Get him one of the Russian beers. We've got those Russian news guys on board and it'll look good in the papers.
answer: C'mon Shep. I've been eating borscht and drinking vodka for days. Isn't that enough? New home starts are down. Fill this with Heineken. I don't believe this. I'm playing politics with a bottle of beer. A goddamn bottle of beer. I've been in office too long.

question: Look on the bright side... if the polls don't change, you won't have that problem, sir.
answer: Yeah. Put the Duke game on in my room. Defense and State Department in the conference room in one hour. I want to review the Iraq situation.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Get me the Housing Secretary...

question: C'mon Alice, we're 20 minutes late.
answer: It's not like he hasn't made us wait a few times.

question: Well, you aren't the President, dear.
answer: Yeah, no duh.

question: Why don't you go say hi? What is wrong with you tonight? Come here. You don't want to say hi to your father?
answer: I'm sure he's busy.

question: Don't you even want to ask?
answer: If I go over there to say hi to daddy President, Mike's going to tell me he's in a meeting and can't be disturbed. Then when the plane starts to taxi, he'll come out and say "Hey, are you guys back? Did you enjoy the ballet?" But he'll be on his way to another meeting and won't wait for an answer. Then you'll get pissed at him and he'll get pissed at you. It's like you guys rehearse or something. Hey Joey, how `bout a cocoa, double whip cream.

question: Alice...
answer: Mom, just this once, give it a rest.

question: You're jet-lagged. We'll talk about this back...
answer: Back at The Fishbowl?

question: We'll talk at home. You know, most girls aren't as lucky as you. For most girls seeing the Bolshoi ballet would be the experience of a lifetime.
answer: I know, Mom. It was great... really. He's in a meeting. He can't be disturbed.

question: I'm sorry, honey.
answer: No, it's okay. After all, he is the President, right? When I write my memoirs I think I'll devote an entire chapter to the cocoa aboard Air Force One.

question: Your father never means to be so...
answer: I know... But lotsa times I feel like it's me versus the world. Some kid at school teases me and the same day a plague breaks out in Bangladesh. I mean it doesn't take a genius to figure which is more important.

question: Some kids were teasing you?
answer: That's not really the point.

question: You're right and I'll tell you a secret. I know exactly how you feel.
answer: Big secret. You said the same thing to Newsweek. We're taxiing. Ready. And... five... four... three.. two... one... Cue Daddy. Oooooh, I'm good.

question: May I speak to you for a moment?
answer: Can't it wait?

question: No, Mr. President. It can't. Don't. I know spin control when I feel it.
answer: Rose, I don't have time for this.

question: For godsakes, Jim, slow down and stop acting like the little dutch boy. Not even you can plug all the world's leaks. Don't you think it's a sign you're pushing too hard when your daughter sees more of you on MTV news than in person.
answer: She's a big girl. She understands.

question: How do you know she understands? You haven't spent more than five minutes with her, or me, in weeks.
answer: And when have I had five minutes? When I wake up in the morning and I'm already three hours behind Schedule. What do you want me to do, Rose, tell the G7 to fuck off because I'm a family man?

question: No. It wasn't.
answer: You know what?

question: What?
answer: I miss you. And I miss her.

question: But that's the point, Jim. We're right here.
answer: I wish it were that easy... I'll make it up to you, I promise.

question: I should trust that promise? Because you know the voters are still waiting for that middle class tax cut.
answer: This promise isn't subject to Congressional approval.

question: How did your speech go?
answer: Well, they aren't burning me in effigy. That's always a good sign. Look on the bright side, hon. Shep here thinks I'll be a one termer.

question: What's going on?
answer: We're under attack.

question: Where's my family?
answer: We're handling it, sir.

question: The launch codes! Who's protecting the football?
answer: Don't open the door!

question: Get in! Get in, sir.
answer: What about my family?

question: One.
answer: But...

question: Okay, 30,000 feet. Give me my heading.
answer: Bearing 110 point eight two.

question: Call me if something changes.
answer: That's it?

question: To fly a 747 you need to know three things. How to take of f, how to land, and how to engage the autopilot.
answer: The rest of the secret service?

question: Dead.
answer: How many others killed?

question: Nine.
answer: Any of us?

question: No damages.
answer: Where's my daughter?

question: She's alive, ma'am, for the time being.
answer: And my husband?

question: The secret service did their job, ma'am. The President is safely off the plane. But that still leaves us plenty to bargain with.
answer: Mr. Gibbs. You, of all people...

question: If we're dealing with an airborne hostage situation what's our procedure?
answer: Our only policy assumes the plane is on the ground. Our hands are completely tied while they're in the air.

question: Okay, Gentlemen, we'll take no action until we confirm that the president is off the plane... Lee, go huddle with the D.O.D. I want an options paper on this in 20 minutes.
answer: Twenty minutes?

question: Find that voice for me, I want to know who we're dealing with. And get President Petrov on the phone.
answer: Madame Vice-President, we just got word from Ramstein... The nod was UntiL Chandler stands.

question: Empty?
answer: The President... he must still be onboard.

question: Yes. You've made yourself quite clear. By then I'll be President. I don't like any of these. from, did you brief General Northwood? Can we do that?
answer: We've got four hours before they make it into Turkienistan airspace.

question: But they start executing hostages in
answer: I hate to be pragmatic, but they'll sacrifice pawns before kings. It may take them some time to kill their way up to senior staff.

question: Leave my daughter alone.
answer: Or you will do what, Mrs. Marshall? But I admire your courage. Your husband, on the other hand...

question: What do you know of my husband?
answer: I know he left you behind.

question: My husband is a very courageous man.
answer: Your husband is a coward. He sends soldiers half-way around the world to steal a man from his home in the middle of the night.

question: Your husband is a coward. He sends soldiers half-way around the world to steal a man from his home in the middle of the night.
answer: You're one of Stravanavitch's men.

question: So, you study world events, little one. That's good for a girl your age.
answer: Yeah, I study world events. Five thousand Turkienistan Muslims were slaughtered in Stravanvitch's cleansings... along with 15 American school kids. You know hQw I studied that. I went to their funerals with my dad. I met their parents.

question: Smart for your age, eh? Top of your class? Tell me, do you know what the word "propaganda" means?
answer: Yeah. Do you know what the word "asshole" means.

question: White House switchboard. How may I direct your call.
answer: Okay listen, listen carefully. This is an emergency call from Air Force One. Who's there? Is the Vice- President there?

question: who can I say is calling? Yeah, right.
answer: Don't cut me off. This is an emergency.

question: Sir, the President does not call this particular number. So whoever you are get a life, before I have this call traced.
answer: You don't understand. This is an emergency. Let me talk to anyone.

question: Okay... if you're the President, when's your wife's birthday?
answer: Look lady, I don't have time for games. Just put the....

question: Thank you for calling the white House...
answer: No. no. no. Wait. Wait. I should know this.

question: Maybe they don't have him yet. And maybe we aren't so helpless.
answer: Everything we own is in that plane. Theoretically.

question: Ramutein Tower Control, please.
answer: But the effect could be jarring.

question: Not so powerful now, eh? No aides to advise you, no secret service to protect you, no armies to command. You'll suffer for what you've done.
answer: * So will you.

question: Up. Get up now! You will walk ahead... slowly. Do you understand? Do you understand!
answer: Do you know what's going to happen to you because of this? Do you know what the world will do?

question: We're okay.
answer: Remarkable aircraft. Remarkable.

question: why did they do that?
answer: Psychology. They're trying to unnerve us.

question: Well it worked.
answer: Relax, my friend. Apparently they cannot harm us. Even if they wanted to. rNT. FRONT GALLEY.

question: Did they say anything about my family?
answer: They're still alive, but the loyalists plan to start killing hostages in forty minutes.

question: Then tell me there's a rescue operation underway.
answer: and if that means negotiating...

question: You know my policy. We don't negotiate with terrorists. If we start now, all of America becomes a target.
answer: But this is different, sir. You're the President. Please, Mr. President. You're going to get yourself killed. Is that your solution?

question: Do you have to be so brutal?
answer: Yes

question: Why? Do you enjoy it?
answer: I neither enjoy nor dislike. I do what is necessary.

question: How can you? I mean they're people.
answer: But they are not ny people. You look at me as if I am a monster, but answer me this -- when your planes bombed the oil fields of Iraq, did You cry for those dark skinned men whose names you do not know and who's faces You will never see? Did You cry for their wives and children. They were people too, yes... but they were not your people.

question: That was war.
answer: So is this. Come now, you're upsetting the little one.

question: Do you see the maintenance panel?
answer: Got it.

question: Pop it open. There should be a red switch, toggle it up.
answer: Okay, it's on. We've got some indicator lights here.

question: Okay, you're aerated. To dump the fuel you have to close the circuit for the pump. There's no switch in Avionics so you'll have to cross the wires. There should be five wires, just to your left. Do you see them?
answer: Got `en.

question: Okay, hang on. Let me double check
answer: I'll wait.

question: First... cut... green wire.
answer: It's cut.

question: cross it... The static overwhelms the voice, then cuts out.
answer: An emergency landing in friendly territory... there's your goddamn miracle.

question: He's down here. I can feel it.
answer: Shut up and do your job.

question: The valve is shut. This guy sure knew what he was doing. You see him?
answer: Erring on the side of caution.

question: We've stopped dumping... but we've only got about twenty minutes of fuel left.
answer: We're not going to make it.

question: Not even close. Hell, we can't even make Syria or Iraq.
answer: Where are we now?

question: Over the Black Sea. I can probably get us to Turkey or Georgia.
answer: No! If we land this plane anywhere else, we will end up another Entebe. The Americans built a super plane that flies through mushroom cloud, evades missiles and... refuels in mid-air. Call the White House.

question: They've cut communication, and I spent a good bit of time looking for alternatives. My only solution ran out of batteries.
answer: The fax machines.

question: Excuse me?
answer: The fax machines.

question: No good. I said they disabled the communications system.
answer: No. I thought about this, Mr.

question: Where's that goddamn plane? tNT.
answer: A KC-135, the USAF flying gas station, descends in front of Air Force One.

question: About goddamn time. Air Force One, acknowledged. tNT.
answer: The KC-135 extends its flying gas pump.

question: Roger KC-135 PILOT That's affirmative.
answer: As Air Force One edges its nose up to the appendage. The appendage finds it's grove and slides right in.

question: What about them?
answer: Sir, we stay with the President.

question: That isn't necessary. Thank you.
answer: Relax everybody. I used to do this for a living9 Caidwell pulls a switch on the wall. Depressurizing compartment. This `11 take a moment.

question: Special Agent Gibbs. You helped do this?
answer: Yes, Mr. President.

question: Why?
answer: Because it is my duty.

question: You're duty to what? The country you served doesn't exist anymore.
answer: My loyalty was never to my country.

question: Three... Two. . One...
answer: NO! Stop.

question: You'll do it?
answer: Yes, I'll do it. Just leave my family alone.

question: Good. Good. Bring him the phone...
answer: Someday, you'll regret my nature.

question: Can my husband sit next to me? I don't know why you stayed.
answer: Please... don't start with me.

question: There's something I need to tell you... and God knows if I'll ever get another chance. No matter what happens, you have been and always will be my hero.
answer: And you have always been my guardian angel.

question: You're very valuable. And our nation needs so many things.
answer: Could I... Could I have some water?

question: The taste of defeat is bitter, no?
answer: One thing I've learned as

question: e Very poetic.
answer: And there's one thing I've learned from being a sports fan.

question: And that is?
answer: It ain't over, til it's over.

question: Petrov. What is it?
answer: It's about Stravanvaitch.

question: What about him?
answer: He's dead, sir. Shot while trying to escape.

question: Stay where you are. There goes your ride.
answer: Let my daughter go or I'll take you out!

question: If you put down the gun, I promise not to drop her on the way down.
answer: Let her go now! Or I will kill you.

question: No you won't. You'll compromise... like always.
answer: Hold on, Alice.

question: This is President Marshall. I know you guys are busy, but we need some help here.
answer: Mr. President, it's an honor. Now with your permission can we lead you the fuck out of here.

question: You read my mind.
answer: Put your pilot on.

question: He's busy being dead.
answer: Who's flying the fucking plane?

question: I'm doing what I can. Negative. We've lost navagition. I don't know where that is.
answer: Oh shit. Hang on. Somebody help me out. I got one up my ass.

question: Two and three are heading toward the Boeing. Okay. We're gonna arc a fat one to the right. Got it?
answer: Got it.

question: Stay cool.
answer: How we doing, Colonel?

question: We still got three MiGs running around and six more on the way.
answer: We're at full throttle. Well get `em off me, goddamnit.

question: Romeo Tango Zulu, do you copy? Do you have the President?
answer: We copy. Stand by... Tower?

question: Tower, here.
answer: This is Romeo Tango Zulu changing call signs. Tower, alert air traffic, Romeo Tango Zulu is now Air Force One. This is Air Force One... The President is safe onboard.
